newsitem.title: KUWAIT: Iraq suspends threats, U.S. Stealth planes land.
newsitem.headline: Iraq suspends threats, U.S. Stealth planes land.

text.p: Iraq abruptly dropped its threat to shoot at western planes patrolling its airspace on Friday, hours after U.S. Stealth bombers arrived in Kuwait as part of a major U.S. military buildup in the Gulf.

President Saddam Hussein's ruling Revolutionary Command Council "has decided today to suspend our military reaction (until further notice)...as of 2400 local time (2000 GMT)," the Iraqi News Agency reported.

The United States, which had dispatched a second aircraft carrier as well as Stealth aircraft and B-52 long-range bombers to confront Iraq, said immediately it would be "looking at actions not statements."

But the Iraqi agency, quoting an official spokesman for the ruling Revolutionary Command Council, said Baghdad still considered the no-fly zones over northern and southern Iraq -- patrolled by western aircraft but closed to Iraqi planes -- to be illegitimate.

The withdrawal of its vow to shoot at planes flying over its territory followed a vow of no "surrender". Iraq, which a week ago said it no longer recognized the five-year-old no-fly zones, had accused U.S. President Bill Clinton of arrogance.

"We are much smaller than America, which has a great power," Iraq's Deputy Prime Minister Tareq Aziz said in an interview with Russian television. "But what shall we do? "Shall we surrender? Definitely not, because American greed knows no limit."
The preparations for an attack on Iraq produced criticism of Clinton from both directions -- with critics at home saying he has shown weakness and those abroad urging restraint.
Top U.S. security officials met at the White House on Friday to plan the next move in their response to Iraq firing missiles at U.S. air patrols over Iraq.
Eight F-117A Stealth fighters landed in Kuwait about dusk on Friday but the aircraft carrier Enterprise, carrying another 75 warplanes, was unlikely to be in the Gulf until Sunday.

The Stealth planes, which can evade radar, used laser-guided 2,000 pound bombs to hit key targets in Baghdad during the 1991 Gulf War when a U.S.-led coalition drove Saddam's occupation forces from Kuwait.

The aircraft carrier Enterprise, with 75 warplanes, was steaming from the Adriatic Sea to the Gulf via the Suez Canal to join the carrier Carl Vinson. The two ships have F-14 fighters adapted to carry accurate laser-guided bombs.
The United States had already moved long-range B-52 bombers to a British base on the Indian Ocean island of Diego Garcia, within striking distance of Iraq.

The bombers were used to launch cruise missile strikes against Iraq last week in reprisal for moving troops into the Kurdish north of Iraq, a region closed to Iraqi forces and under Western protection for the past five years.
In another echo of the Gulf War, the U.S. Army said it was activating two Patriot anti-missile batteries, used to defend Saudi Arabia and Israel against Iraqi Scud missiles in 1991.
"I think they (Saddam's government) really only understand disproportionate force," said former U.S. Secretary of State James Baker, who helped build the coalition for the Gulf War.
But divisions in the coalition that fought Iraq five years ago, already apparent after the U.S. missile strikes last week, continued to grow.
Turkey, which provides a base for western aircraft to protect Kurds in northern Iraq against Saddam, warned against further U.S. strikes and called for a diplomatic strategy.
China said on Friday it strongly opposed a U.S. attack on Iraq, saying such problems should be resolved under United Nations resolutions.
Russia, another of the five permanent members of the Security Council that had approved the Gulf War, sounded a similar warning on Thursday. France also expressed concern.

Although Washington made clear its priority was in southern Iraq, near the oil-rich Gulf states, the crisis began with Saddam's military backing for a Kurdish faction that secured control of northern Iraq this week.
Iraq underlined its renewed influence in the north after five years, saying on Friday it had resume sending fuel supplies to the Kurdish region.
But fear of Saddam's return to the north prompted Kurds opposed to the Baghdad government or with links to the West -- military and aid organisations -- to flee.
Turkey's ambassador to Washington, Nuzhet Kandemir, said Ankara was providing aircraft to help the United States fly 2,500 Americans, Kurds and Iraqi dissidents from northern Iraq.
The United Nations refugee agency UNHCR said in Geneva it had confirmed that 30,000 other Iraqi Kurds were now in Iran.
